field_edited_text.value:
24

The estimates for rehabilitating buildings with
various degrees of dilapidation fell between the
following ranges:

Standard

Deficient - 1st degree
Deficient - 2nd degree
Substandard

$ 4,000-$ 5,000
$ 5,000 - $10,000
$10,000 - $17,000
$12,000 - $25,000

These figures were compared to property values
and a ratio established. Assuming an average
property value of $10,000 and using this ratio,
costs were estimated for the rehabilitation of a
commercial building in keeping with the goals
of the program. By categories of deficiency, the
following average costs were derived:

Standard $ 4,200
Deficient - 1st degree $ 6,500
Deficient - 2nd degree $12,100

Substandard $16,200

The study showed no apparent direct
relationship between the size of the business,
building condition or assessed value, and the
amount spent on rehabilitation improvements.
Rehabilitation had been undertaken or was
being considered even with buildings in poor or
bad condition.

It was concluded that the question of whether
rehabilitation could be considered feasible
could not be readily resolved. The extent to
which an owner or merchant would be willing
to invest further sums in a property appeared to
rest primarily on three factors: his financial
capability to undertake rehabilitation, the
competitive position of the business and the
anticipated return on his investment.

Other considerations which appeared to
influence the decision to undertake
rehabilitation were examined. They included a
number of individual factors, such as whether

the building was owned or rented, whether it
was a chain store or locally owned, the location
of the business and the effect of competition
and the availability of financing.

The merchant considering rehabilitation may
also be influenced in his decision if a strong
improvement program is contemplated
throughout his area. With group participation
by merchants, a snowballing effect is likely to
take place resulting in rehabilitation being
undertaken by more merchants. An areawide
improvement program could also offer the
attractions of city assistance, additional loan
sources and improved enforcement of codes
and ordinances.

Codes and ordinances controlling the
rehabilitation of existing buildings were
examined as part of this study and several
modifications suggested to make rehabilitation
more feasible.
